ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: some asynchronous classes where students had to respond to a Canvas discussion after watching a pre-recorded lecture. Most classes were synchronous seminar discussions.
Discussion posts, film in media library, recorded lectures.
We sometimes had prerecorded lectures. We also had additional and optional lectures to chat w/ + learn from various filmmakers.
We had recorded lectures, lectures before seminar, and breakout room discussions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained insight into the Japanese film industry and how Japanese history shaped it. We explored different genres of Japanese film (anime, pink film, yakuza, samuri) as well as different cultural, political, and economic trends that accompanied the emergence of different genres.
Deep understanding of the status of Japanese Cinema both historically and presently in accordance to the national cinema's trends and themes.

-briefest introduction to postmodern Japanese literature 
-helpful periodizations of pre + postwar Japanese cinema 
-sharpened close film analysis 
-detailed look at particular filmmakers' style + influences
I learned a lot about the history of Japanese cinema and the Japanese film industry as well as learning about more formal elements of filmic analysis.
A lot of Japanese culture and movie history

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of the course are the exposure to so many different kinds of Japanese cinema. The weakness would be the sheer amount of reading necessary to have foundational discussions about said cinema became quite overwhelming at times. Furthermore, the desired paper style was not completely clear, even after reading Professor Gerow's guide on writing papers for film.

Strengths: Really great diversity in films. Really appreciated when the professor decided to experiment with the films on the syllabus. Nice breaks provided by the prerecorded lecture. Breakout room and clip viewing was more sophisticated with my other courses--very swift usage of tech this semester. I felt I was able to learn a great deal from both the instructor and the grad students. The professor is skilled at maximizing learning and keeping assignments/workload at a reasonable level.
Weaknesses: Wish we could have dwelled on a few units for a little long but this may be hard to achieve what w/ the survey nature of the course.
The films were well chosen and always engaging. The lecture material, too.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Gerow really did everything in his power to make this an engaging course over zoom. He utilized discussion boards, the whiteboard feature, power points, and guest speakers. Towards the end of the semester, he also made classes asynchronous to accommodate students in different time zones.

As described above, the lecture format [we could see Professor Gerow in the bottom of his slideshows] was particularly engaging. Measured usage of discussion posts in lieu of class. We did this frequently enough + these were strategically and lovingly scheduled. It was a relief meeting asynchronously during the election, midterm season, and the general stress of this semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are interested in Japanese culture or film. The films that Prof Gerow selects are pretty interesting, and they usually aren't too long. Many of them were only around 90 minutes long, which is pretty rare for film majors who are used to taking seminars with back to back screenings of 2.5 hour films. Combined with the films, the reading can be a bit extensive, but it is definitely manageable. I found the historical readings more interesting than the academic/philosophical ones as many of the readings were quite dense and convoluted. Prof Gerow is great, and his power points at the beginning of class are well-organized introductions into the theme of each class. However, I do think this class could have functioned better as a small lecture ~25-35 students as opposed to a seminar.  Half of the class was entirely lecture, and students' engagement was centered around answering specific questions rather than back-and-forth discussions.

I would recommend this course to someone who has taken at least one film class before! I think the environment could be at times intense given the expertise of the instructor and the expertise of the grad students. Be prepared to use your critical thinking skills [perhaps to a greater degree than other classes here] and take many notes.
Yes. Prof. Gerow was a great professor and the material was very engaging. It is an awesome course for anyone interested in Japanese film or film studies more generally.
Yes. This course teaches a lot about Japan and Japanese films. It is very engaging
